title: BrainGnomes Quickstart
text: BrainGnomes R package streamlines preprocessing analysis fMRI data high-performance computing (HPC) clusters. serves wrapper around common fMRI processing tools HeuDiConv (DICOM--BIDS conversion), BIDS Validator, MRIQC (quality control), fMRIPrep (preprocessing pipeline), ICA-AROMA (automatic removal motion artifacts), orchestrating execution coherent pipeline. package also provides additional processing steps preparing fMRI data analysis, spatial smoothing, temporal filtering, confound regression. BrainGnomes uses containerized software (Singularity images) ensure reproducible environments imaging tools manages job submission HPC schedulers (SLURM TORQUE). tutorial, walk full workflow setting running fMRI preprocessing study using BrainGnomes. cover three key functions: setup_project(): Initialize new study configuration (either scratch existing YAML configuration file) edit_project(): Interactively review modify study configuration sections run_project(): Execute preprocessing pipeline steps dataset, utilizing HPC environment Along way, assume required Singularity container images tool working HPC environment. Additional information setting compute environment provided BrainGnomes Singularity container setup. vignette provides example R code snippets, explains expected inputs/outputs, offers troubleshooting tips common issues. end demo, new user understand configure study launch BrainGnomes pipeline start finish. package designed run HPC clusters use SLURm TORQUE. designed run standard computer.

title: Extracting ROI Timeseries and Connectivity
text: atlas region contains many voxels. roi_reduce argument controls voxel time series combined single ROI signal: mean – averages voxels (default). median – takes median reduce sensitivity outliers. pca – extracts first principal component aligns sign mean, capturing dominant pattern variation. huber – applies Huber M‑estimator robust trimmed mean.

title: Extracting ROI Timeseries and Connectivity
text: Connectivity matrices optional governed cor_method argument. Multiple methods may supplied. Supported options include: pearson – standard product–moment correlation. spearman – rank‑based correlation robust non‑linear monotonic relationships. kendall – Kendall’s ordinal small sample data. cor.shrink – shrinkage estimator corpcor package, useful number ROIs large relative number time points. rtoz flag applies Fisher’s zz transform correlations, producing unbounded values better suited group analysis.

text: setup_apply_mask() controls whether apply binary brain mask BOLD runs. prompt explains rationale lets provide mask file output prefix. Options include path mask file (mask_file) prefix masked output (prefix, default "m").【F:R/setup_postprocess.R†L496-L544】
code: Applying a brain mask to your fMRI data ensures that only in-brain voxels are retained during analysis. This step is optional but often recommended for improving efficiency and accuracy in subsequent processing. The mask will be applied as a binary filter to the 4D functional data, zeroing out signal outside the brain. You can specify a custom mask file (in the same space and resolution as your fMRI data), or use the default mask produced by your preprocessing pipeline. Do you want to apply a brain mask to your fMRI data?

title: BrainGnomes Postprocessing Walkthrough
text: Spatial smoothing applies 3D Gaussian kernel BOLD fMRI data, typically increases signal--noise ratio improves overlap across subjects reducing high-frequency spatial noise. asked specify size smoothing kernel millimeters (full width half maximum, FWHM). Common choices range 4mm 8mm. Smoothing achieved using FSL’s susan command, applies nonlinear filtering algorithm seeks smooth together voxels similar intensities. Technical details
code: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Spatial smoothing applies a 3D Gaussian kernel to the BOLD fMRI data, which increases  the signal-to-noise ratio and improves overlap across subjects by reducing high-frequency spatial noise.  You will be asked to specify the size of the smoothing kernel in millimeters (full width at half maximum, or FWHM). Common choices range from 4mm to 8mm.  Do you want to apply spatial smoothing to the BOLD data as part of postprocessing?  Apply spatial smoothing? (yes/no) > y Spatial smoothing FWHM (mm) > 5

title: BrainGnomes Postprocessing Walkthrough
text: ICA-AROMA denoising applied postprocessing, must enable project configuration must run point (.e., Run ICA-AROMA? run_project()). produce set output files, including *_desc-MELODIC_mixing.tsv (mixing matrix), contains spatiotemporal components identified noise signal algorithm. ICA‑AROMA outputs available, can regress noise components postprocessing step. Building original papers (Pruim et al., 2015), recommend ‘nonaggressive’ removal, removes variance ‘noise’ components correlated signal components (.e., partial effects multiple regression). detailed , AROMA applied fMRI data, components also regressed confounds. Note 8Aug2025, nonaggressive denoising supported, regardless respond prompts.
code: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ICA-AROMA identifies motion-related independent components from the fMRI data and outputs noise regressors (e.g., *_desc-aroma_timeseries.tsv) that can be used to denoise the BOLD signal. The pipeline asks you decide about whether to run the data through ICA-AROMA, which generates various files, but does not make any changes to the fMRI data.  Here, you can denoise the data using ICA-AROMA, which step applies the noise regressors to the data using voxelwise regression, either:   - nonaggressively (recommended), which removes *unique* variance from noise components only, or   - aggressively, which removes all variance associated with the noise components.  Do you want to apply ICA-AROMA denoising during postprocessing?  Apply AROMA denoising? (yes/no) > y Use nonaggressive denoising? (yes/no; Press enter to accept default: yes) > y

title: BrainGnomes Postprocessing Walkthrough
text: Temporal filtering removes low- /high-frequency components fMRI time series. high-pass filter (e.g., 0.008 Hz) commonly used remove slow scanner drift, low-pass filter can remove physiological noise respiratory cardiac fluctuations. Temporal filtering common task-based resting-state fMRI analyses. task fMRI, often apply gentle high-pass filter (e.g. .008 Hz) remove low-frequency drift can weaken GLM analyses assume constant baseline. resting-state analyses, people often bandpass filter. support fslmaths -bptf Butterworth temporal filter. former common task-based fMRI latter resting-state fMRI. filtering enabled, asked choose filtering methods. Per FSL’s documentation, -bptf uses local fit straight line (Gaussian-weighted within line give smooth response) remove low frequency artifacts. preferable sharp rolloff FIR-based filtering introduce autocorrelations data. ‘ringing artifacts’ can induce negative autocorrelations, interfere GLM software correects autocorrelation (e.g., Tukey tapering FSL feat). Low-pass temporal filtering reduces high frequency noise Gaussian smoothing, also reduces strength signal interest, particularly single-event experiments. Butterworth filtering common temporal filtering technique used fMRI postprocessing attenuate low-frequency drifts /high-frequency noise preserving passband signal minimal distortion. Unlike sharp cutoff filters, Butterworth filter maximally flat frequency response passband, making well-suited applications requiring smooth transitions. fMRI, typically applied band-pass high-pass filter remove slow scanner drifts physiological noise outside frequency range interest (e.g., 0.01–0.1 Hz resting-state analyses). avoid phase distortion, BrainGnomes applies filter bidirectionally (.e., using forward reverse passes). BrainGnomes also uses second-order Butterworth filter, good balance frequency precision smooth rolloff (higher orders give precise frequency control edges, bigger risks artifacts). One virtues FSL’s Gaussian line smoothing approach gradual rolloff. said, frequency response broad sharply defined, can lead partial attenuation signals near cutoff (e.g., upper cutoff .10 Hz, might still see attenuation .09 Hz). Butterworth filter precise control frequencies retained data may slightly higher risk messing autocorrelation structure (due ringing). order prompts example responses. Note skip one cutoffs (press enter prompt), side filter applied. example, enter low-pass cutoff Apply temporal filtering? > yes Low-pass cutoff (Hz) (Press enter skip) > 0.009 High-pass cutoff (Hz)  (Press enter skip) > 0.08 Filtering method (fslmaths/butterworth) > butterworth

title: BrainGnomes Postprocessing Walkthrough
text: ‘Scrubbing’ refers set procedures reducing impact high-motion/high-artifact volumes fMRI analysis. typical approach flag volumes based framewise displacement, measure overall head displacement direction/rotation, remove volumes time series. said, scrubbing encompasses wider range decisions, whether interpolate bad timepoints whether generate spike regressors leaving fMRI data intact (e.g., subsequent use task-based analysis). Importantly, scrubbing tricky interactions postprocessing steps, especially confound regression temporal filtering. Temporal filtering removes specific frequencies data, simply delete volumes time series hope filtering work intended. Moreover, apply temporal filter prior scrubbing, can induce ‘ringing artifacts’ large signal changes due head motion propagated adjacent timepoints (Carp, 2012, NeuroImage). One effective way handle interpolate bad volumes (cubic spline common), apply temporal filter, later scrub bad (now interpolated) timepoints. nilearn XCP-D approach problem. BrainGnomes also allows spline interpolation precursor temporal filtering. Another scrubbing interaction occurs confound regression. plan regress confound signals fMRI, want maximize denoising volumes ultimately wish analyze, volumes plan scrub . Consequently, either ) run confound regression scrubbing b) optimize fit regression model good timepoints. Aligned XCP-D pipeline, adopt latter strategy, fitting confound model good timepoints. allows (potentially interpolated) high-motion timepoints retained final fMRI timeseries. Typically, remove/scrub , analysis requires intact timeseries (e.g., frequency-based analysis), perhaps ’d like keep timepoints.

what: An R package for preprocessing and analyzing fMRI data
title: An R package for preprocessing and analyzing fMRI data
text: BrainGnomes streamlines preprocessing analysis fMRI data high performance computing (HPC) clusters. package wraps common neuroimaging tools (HeuDiConv, MRIQC, fMRIPrep others) provides helper functions managing configuration files, submitting jobs running post‑processing steps. heavy weight dependencies executed Singularity containers pipelines reproducible across systems.

title: An R package for preprocessing and analyzing fMRI data
text: Documentation provided several vignettes found vignettes/ folder: BrainGnomes Quickstart – end end introduction setting running study vignettes/braingnomes_quickstart.Rmd. Building Singularity containers BrainGnomes – instructions creating container images used pipeline vignettes/building_containers.Rmd. BrainGnomes Postprocessing Walkthrough – details optional post‑processing utilities smoothing, scrubbing denoising vignettes/postprocessing.Rmd.

title: An R package for preprocessing and analyzing fMRI data
text: Core functionality resides handful scripts: R/setup_project.R – interactive functions creating validating project configuration files. R/process_subject.R – runs preprocessing single participant. R/run_project.R – orchestrates multi‑subject pipelines cluster. R/pipeline_functions.R – utilities job scripts pipeline bookkeeping. src/ – C++ helpers filtering, interpolation fast numerical routines. inst/hpc_scripts/ – SLURM TORQUE templates submitting container jobs. Together components allow BrainGnomes manage full workflow raw BIDS conversion fMRIPrep optional post‑processing steps.

title: Apply a Butterworth Filter to a 4D NIfTI Image — butterworth_filter_4d
text: infile Character string. Path input 4D NIfTI file. tr Numeric. repetition time (TR) seconds. low_hz Numeric NULL. Low cutoff frequency Hz high-pass bandpass filtering. high_hz Numeric NULL. High cutoff frequency Hz low-pass bandpass filtering. outfile Character string. provided, filtered image written file. internal Logical. FALSE (default), returns niftiImage object voxel values; TRUE, returns minimal metadata internal object (see RNifti). order Integer. Filter order (default = 4). padtype Character string. Padding strategy: "even", "odd", "constant", "zero". Default "even". use_zi Logical. Whether use steady-state initial conditions (default = TRUE). demean Logical. Whether demean timeseries prior filtering. Usually good remove DC (mean) component (default = true).

code: cluster_job_submit(   script,   scheduler = "slurm",   sched_args = NULL,   env_variables = NULL,   export_all = FALSE,   echo = TRUE,   fail_on_error = FALSE,   wait_jobs = NULL,   wait_signal = "afterok",   repolling_interval = 60,   tracking_sqlite_db = NULL,   tracking_args = list() )

title: This function submits a single script to a high-performance cluster using a scheduler (Slurm or TORQUE). It accepts a vector of arguments to be passed to the scheduler and a vector of environment variables that should be passed to the compute node at job execution. — cluster_job_submit
text: script path script executed scheduler single command run. script point existing file, treated one-line command execute. case conflicts, directives passed sched_args take precedence. scheduler scheduler use job submission. Options 'qsub', 'torque', 'sbatch', 'slurm', 'sh'. terms 'qsub' 'torque' aliases ('torque' submits via qsub command). Likewise 'sbatch' 'slurm'. scheduler 'sh' submit scheduler , instead executes command immediately via sh. sched_args character vector arguments included scheduling command. TORQUE, typically begin '-l' '-l wall_time=10:00:00'. env_variables named character vector containing environment variables values passed script execution time. handled '-v' directive TORQUE clusters '–export' Slurm clusters. names vector environment variable names values vector environment variable values passed . want propagate current value environment variable compute node runtime, use NA value element env_variables. See examples. export_all Whether export environment variables compute node runtime. Default: FALSE echo Whether echo job submission command terminal time scheduled. Default: TRUE. fail_on_error Whether stop execution script (TRUE), issue warning (FALSE) job submission fails. Defaults FALSE (.e., issue warning). wait_jobs character string jobs process ids complete job executed wait_signal torque slurm clusters, signal indicate parent jobs finished. repolling_interval number seconds wait rechecking job status (used local scheduler) tracking_sqlite_db Path SQLite database used job tracking. provided, job submission metadata recorded, including job dependencies parent-child relationships. tracking_args named list metadata fields track submitted job. may include parent job ID, batch script path, scheduler options. used conjunction tracking_sqlite_db support job tracking.

title: This function submits a single script to a high-performance cluster using a scheduler (Slurm or TORQUE). It accepts a vector of arguments to be passed to the scheduler and a vector of environment variables that should be passed to the compute node at job execution. — cluster_job_submit
text: Michael Hallquist

title: This function submits a single script to a high-performance cluster using a scheduler (Slurm or TORQUE). It accepts a vector of arguments to be passed to the scheduler and a vector of environment variables that should be passed to the compute node at job execution. — cluster_job_submit
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   #simple PBS submission   cluster_job_submit('myscript.bash', scheduler="torque",       sched_args=c('-l walltime=10:00:00', '-l nodes=1:ppn=20'),      env_variables=c(RUN_INDEX=2, MODEL_NAME='FSE21'))    #To forward environment variables without explicitly providing values. Note that these must   #  be in R's system environment (cf. Sys.getenv) at execution time to forward as expected.   cluster_job_submit('myscript.sbatch', scheduler="slurm",      sched_args=c('-p general', '-N 1', '-n 12', '--mem=10g', '-t 02-00:00:00'),      env_variables=c(RUN_INDEX=2, R_HOME=NA, JAVA_HOME=NA))    # submit a single command without a script file   cluster_job_submit('echo "hello"', scheduler="slurm") } # }

what: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
title: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
text: function constructs regular expression match BIDS-compatible filenames based set entity-value pairs. resulting pattern allows intermediate unspecified entities matched ones ensures correct ordering based BIDS specification. supports full entity names common abbreviations (e.g., sub, ses, task, desc, etc.).

title: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
text: spec character string specifying BIDS entities key:value pairs separated spaces. example: "sub:01 task:rest desc:preproc suffix:bold". Abbreviated keys supported. pass custom regex directly, prefix input "regex:" (e.g., "regex:^sub-.*_bold\\.nii\\.gz$"). add_niigz_ext Logical; TRUE (default), automatically appends regex matches .nii .nii.gz extensions (\\.nii(\\.gz)?$) extension explicitly provided.

title: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
text: character string containing regular expression pattern matches BIDS filenames containing specified entities order, allowing intermediate unspecified fields.

title: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
text: suffix provided, regex match suffix (e.g., "bold", "T1w", etc.). ext provided add_niigz_ext = TRUE, pattern match .nii .nii.gz. Unescaped periods user-supplied extensions automatically escaped avoid unintended matches. Intermediate fields (e.g., _acq-lowres_) allowed specified components using (_[^_]+)*_ pattern.

title: Construct a Regular Expression for Matching BIDS Filenames — construct_bids_regex
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   # Match a bold preprocessed run for subject 01 with any other intermediate fields allowed   construct_bids_regex("sub:01 task:rest desc:preproc suffix:bold")    # Match any file that ends in .nii or .nii.gz   construct_bids_regex("suffix:bold")    # Use an explicit regex pattern   construct_bids_regex("regex:^sub-[0-9]+_task-rest_.*\\.nii\\.gz$") } # }

text: Given postprocessed BOLD NIfTI file one atlas images, function computes mean timeseries within ROI optionally computes ROI--ROI correlation matrices.

title: Extract ROI timeseries and connectivity matrices — extract_rois
code: extract_rois(   bold_file,   atlas_files,   out_dir,   log_file = NULL,   cor_method = c("pearson", "spearman", "kendall", "cor.shrink"),   roi_reduce = c("mean", "median", "pca", "huber"),   brain_mask = NULL,   min_vox_per_roi = 5,   save_ts = TRUE,   rtoz = FALSE,   overwrite = FALSE )

title: Extract ROI timeseries and connectivity matrices — extract_rois
text: bold_file Path 4D NIfTI file containing postprocessed BOLD data. atlas_files Character vector atlas NIfTI files integer ROI labels. out_dir Directory output files written. log_file NULL, log file details written. cor_method Correlation method(s) use computing functional connectivity. Supported options include "pearson", "spearman", "kendall", "cor.shrink". Use "none" skip correlation computation. Multiple methods may supplied. roi_reduce Method used summarize voxel time series within ROI. Options "mean" (default), "median", "pca", "huber". brain_mask Optional brain mask NIfTI file. NULL, mask generated excluding voxels zero variance across time. min_vox_per_roi minimum number voxels required ROI extracted entered correlations. ROI smaller , show NA outputs, keeping dimensionality connectivity matrix consistent across inputs. Default: 5 save_ts TRUE, save ROI time series (aggregated using roi_reduce method) _timeseries.tsv. files. Useful running external analyses ROIs. Default: TRUE. rtoz TRUE, using Fisher's z (aka atanh) transformation correlations make continuous unbounded, rather [0,1]. diagonal correlation matrices beccomes 15 approximate 1.0 correlation, rather making Inf. overwrite TRUE, overwrite existing timeseries.tsv connectivity.tsv files.

title: Extract ROI timeseries and connectivity matrices — extract_rois
text: named list. element corresponds atlas contains paths written timeseries (timeseries) correlation matrix (correlation, NULL computed).

One "constant" (default), "odd", "even", "zero". use_zi Logical. TRUE (default), use steady-state initial conditions minimize transients.

Typically includes motion parameters, physiological noise, etc. include_rows Logical vector indicating timepoints include model fitting (e.g., uncensored). Must length number timepoints image number rows X. add_intercept Logical; TRUE, adds intercept column design matrix unless one already present. outfile Optional path write output residuals image. empty, file written. internal Logical; TRUE, returns internal RNifti pointer. Otherwise returns R array. preserve_mean Logical; TRUE, constant time series left unchanged (demeaned recentered). set_mean Optional numeric value; specified, residual time series shifted mean (default 0). used combination preserve_mean = TRUE.

title: Interpolate fMRI Time Series with Cubic Splines in a NIfTI File — natural_spline_4d
text: infile Character string. Path input 4D NIfTI file (e.g., BOLD fMRI data). t_interpolate Integer vector (1-based). Specifies timepoints (TRs) interpolate. Timepoints outside valid range [1, T] ignored warning. edge_nn Logical. TRUE, extrapolated values edges time series filled using nearest-neighbor extrapolation instead cubic splines. outfile Character string (optional). provided, interpolated image written path. omitted, result returned saved. internal Logical. FALSE (default), array class "niftiImage", containing image pixel voxel values, returned. TRUE, return value object class "internalImage", contains minimal metadata image. Either way, return value attribute points C data structure containing full image. Cf. RNifti::readNifti

title: Interpolate fMRI Time Series with Cubic Splines in a NIfTI File — natural_spline_4d
text: niftiImage object dimensions metadata input, interpolated values inserted specified timepoints.

title: Interpolate fMRI Time Series with Cubic Splines in a NIfTI File — natural_spline_4d
text: function reads NIfTI image disk, performs interpolation memory, optionally writes result back new NIfTI file. interpolation voxelwise assumes column-major order. voxel time series fewer three valid (non-interpolated) timepoints, constant across time, skipped. Linear extrapolation used timepoints outside valid range edge_nn = FALSE, matching R's splinefun approach natural splines. edge_nn = TRUE, nearest-neighbor extrapolation used interpolation timepoints beginning end timeseries, potentially reducing extreme values extrapolation. implementation uses RNifti's C++ API (NiftiImage, NiftiImageData) efficient memory access file handling, allowing function operate directly NIfTI files.

title: Interpolate fMRI Time Series with Cubic Splines in a NIfTI File — natural_spline_4d
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ out_img <- natural_spline_4d(   infile = "bold.nii.gz",   t_interpolate = 91:95,   outfile = "bold_interpolated.nii.gz",   edge_nn = TRUE ) } # }
